questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she has not attained menarche. She has no history of serious illness. She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no glandular breast tissue and no pubic hair development. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The GnRH stimulation test is the gold standard for identifying central precocious puberty. This patient lacks signs of puberty such as menarche and breast development and requires further evaluation of primary amenorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

All patients who have not reached menarche by the age of 16 years or have not developed secondary sexual characteristics (breasts, pubic hair) by the age of 13 years must be evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Further tests should be initiated to identify correctable causes and initiate treatment, if necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

The progesterone challenge test is indicated in suspected gonadotropin deficiency (low FSH, LH, and estrogen). Gonadotropin levels of this patient have not been measured yet, therefore, another step is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is only indicated if FSH levels are low and a hypothalamic or pituitary disease (e.g., pituitary tumor) is suspected, which could cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and subsequent primary amenorrhea. This patient does not present with additional symptoms of a process in the sella region, such as headaches, vision changes, or any other signs of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

The evaluation of primary amenorrhea starts with a pelvic examination and a pregnancy test to rule out pregnancy. If pelvic examination confirms the presence of a uterus, serum FSH level should be assessed. A high serum FSH level indicates gonadal dysgenesis, most commonly due to chromosomal aberrations, e.g., in Turner syndrome (45,XO). Causes of a low serum FSH level include constitutional growth delay, functional growth delay (e.g., due to inflammatory bowel disease or chronic kidney disease), and hypothalamic-pituitary disorders (e.g., hemochromatosis, injury, Kallmann syndrome). Further testing depends on the suspected etiology and includes serum TSH and prolactin levels to rule out uncommon causes of primary amenorrhea (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma, hypothyroidism).

In patients with blind or absent vagina on pelvic examination, a pelvic ultrasound should be performed to visualize internal reproductive organs. Congenital reproductive outflow tract obstruction (e.g., imperforate hymen) should be considered if a uterus is present. In patients without a uterus on ultrasound, serum testosterone levels and karyotyping are used to determine the underlying pathology (e.g., Mullerian agenesis, androgen insensitivity syndrome).

Depending on the result of the serum FSH studies, the working diagnosis for this patient could be either gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Swyer syndrome) or a hypothalamic-pituitary disorder (e.g., normosmic isolated GnRH deficiency). Functional or constitutional growth delays are unlikely as the patient is in the 50th percentile for weight and height.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum free and total testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate concentrations is indicated in suspected hyperandrogenism (e.g., patients with male pattern baldness, hirsutism, and acne). Causes include polycystic ovary syndrome, ovarian or adrenal tumors, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and Cushing syndrome. This patient shows no features of a hyperandrogenic state and therefore requires a different test.
questions.hint: Absent or incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 14 years in boys or 13 years in girls indicates delayed puberty. This delay can be constitutional, secondary to underlying conditions, or due to hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to the physician because of erectile dysfunction for the past month. He cannot maintain an erection during intercourse and rarely wakes up with an erection. He says he is happy in his current relationship, but admits to decreased desire for sex and feeling embarrassed about his sexual performance. He sustained a lumbar vertebral injury one year ago following a motor vehicle accident. He takes medication for his schizophrenia but does not remember the name. Physical examination shows testicular atrophy with otherwise normal genitalia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics can cause erectile dysfunction and hypogonadism due to their effects as dopamine antagonists and subsequent disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Dopamine antagonists stimulate prolactin secretion, which leads to the downstream effects of decreased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus, decreased LH secretion from the anterior pituitary, and decreased production of testosterone by Leydig cells in the testes. This results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which would explain this patient's erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and testicular atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Peyronie disease is a fibroproliferative disorder affecting the tunica albuginea of the penis. Patients typically present with penile pain, curving of the penis during an erection, and/or palpable nodules and induration of the penis. This patient has no signs or symptoms of Peyronie disease and his testicular atrophy suggests a different cause of his sexual dysfunction.
Image Description:

Photograph of an erect penis showing an abnormal downward curvature.

C) INCORRECT:

Microvascular disease is a very common cause of erectile dysfunction in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and/or smoking history. Microvascular disease causes endothelial dysfunction and decreased levels of nitric oxide, thereby impairing vasodilation of vessels supplying the corpus cavernosum. However, this patient lacks cardiovascular risk factors and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by microvascular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Afferent fibers from the pudendal nerve transmit sensory stimuli from the external genitalia and perineum to the parasympathetic nervous system, where efferent signals are generated to mediate an erection. Damage to peripheral nerves can interfere with this neural pathway and lead to neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction. This patient has no symptoms of neurologic disorders and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by peripheral nerve injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychologic stressors (e.g., depression, previous traumatic experiences, relationship trouble) are common causes of erectile dysfunction. Patients with psychogenic erectile dysfunction usually get morning erections, but have difficulty getting or maintaining erections during intercourse with a partner. This patient rarely has morning erections and presents with testicular atrophy, making psychologic stressors an unlikely primary cause for his sexual dysfunction.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia is likely being treated with an atypical antipsychotic. These medications can cause hyperprolactinemia, leading to sexual dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man reports fatigue and diminished libido. Starting a year ago, but not before then, his interest in sex waned; he now rarely awakes with an erection, and he achieves only a modest erection when masturbating. He has occasional morning headaches. He has not had any loss of axillary or pubic hair or any history of testicular trauma or infection with mumps. His experience of puberty was normal.
He is divorced and has two healthy children, ages 15 and 17 years.
His BMI is 38. Axillary hair and pubic hair are normal. Each testicle is about 10 cc (reference range, 15–25). Visual fields are intact to confrontation.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Luteinizing hormone (mIU/mL)
2.2
2.0–12.0


Prolactin (ng/mL)
5.2
0–15.0


Total testosterone (ng/dL)
210
270–1070


Sex hormone-binding globulin (nmol/liter)
30
13–71


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.52
0.5–4.7


Free thyroxine (ng/dL)
1.5
0.8–1.8


Which one of the following tests is most likely to establish the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) should be considered in this patient with obesity, hypogonadism, and daytime fatigue. OSA frequently coexists with obesity and has been associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Sleep deprivation results in lowered testosterone levels, as does sleep restriction in the first half of the rest period. Obesity causes both OSA and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

OSA is best diagnosed with a sleep study. Testosterone levels and OSA typically improve after appropriate weight loss treatment, but testosterone levels do not reliably improve by solely applying continuous positive airway pressure for OSA. Ruling out OSA is especially relevant when the use of testosterone is being considered, because untreated severe OSA is a contraindication to the use of testosterone replacement.

Key learning point: Morning headaches and daytime fatigue in a man with obesity and a low testosterone level are most likely to be attributable to obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hypogonadotropic hypogonadism can be due to a congenital disorder such as idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, Kallmann syndrome, or Prader-Willi syndrome, patients with those conditions usually present with symptoms at an early age and do not have a normal puberty experience or a normal reproductive history. Therefore, karyotype testing is not indicated in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Men with a pituitary cause of hypogonadism often have extremely low testosterone levels; pituitary tumors and elevated prolactin levels must be ruled out in adults with recent-onset secondary hypogonadism if the testosterone level is very low. Given that this patient is more likely to have obstructive sleep apnea than a pituitary problem, a sleep study is more appropriate than a pituitary MRI.

D) INCORRECT:

A testicular ultrasound is unlikely to be helpful in evaluating a patient with low gonadotropin levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Although chronic opioid use is a common cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, evaluation for opioid use is unlikely to be diagnostic in the absence of suggestive features, such as surreptitious drug-seeking behavior, particularly in a patient whose symptoms of fatigue and morning headache are consistent with obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man reports recent-onset erectile dysfunction characterized by diminished libido and difficulty obtaining an erection. He has a history of insulin-treated diabetes and depression, for which he sees a psychiatrist and therapist regularly. Three months ago, he started taking fluoxetine for his depression. He had surgery to repair a left inguinal hernia one year ago.
An affirmative answer to which one of the following questions would be most consistent with hypogonadism as a cause of this patient’s erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Have you needed to shave less often?
Do you lose your erection during intercourse?
Are you able to generate an erection with masturbation?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety often experience spontaneous morning erections.

B) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction has multiple possible causes in this case. Diabetes is associated with sexual dysfunction because of damage to nerves and small blood vessels. Depression can cause sexual dysfunction, as can its treatment. Fluoxetine, like all selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, can reduce libido and impair erectile function. However, this patient could also have primary or secondary hypogonadism.

Diabetes, depression, and antidepressants are not typically associated with changes in secondary sexual characteristics, such as loss of body hair, facial hair, or muscle mass. A patient who responds affirmatively to a question about a reduction in shaving frequency should be evaluated for hypogonadism. It should be noted, however, that although a change in shaving frequency is quite specific to hypogonadism, it is not very sensitive; most men with established facial hair growth do not notice a change in such growth when they develop hypogonadism. Therefore, this patient should likely be evaluated further for hypogonadism with testosterone measurements regardless of his shaving frequency.

Key learning point: Symptoms of male hypogonadism include erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, less facial hair, and loss of muscle mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced sexual desire can be a feature of either hypogonadism or depression, so a question about desire or libido does not help distinguish the cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents for evaluation of delayed puberty. He initially began to develop body odor, pubic hair, and axillary hair at age 11 but has not had morning erections, voice changes, or acne. He had a speech delay as a child but is otherwise healthy and takes no medications.
He is 175 cm tall (74th percentile) and weighs 65 kg (77th percentile). On examination, pubic hair is consistent with sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 4, and his testicles are 5 mL in size (SMR 2). He has mild gynecomastia bilaterally. His bone age is consistent with his chronologic age.
Laboratory testing, performed at 8 a.m., yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Testosterone (ng/dL)
79
270–1070


Luteinizing hormone (mIU/mL)
27
0.29–4.77


Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
41
0.85–8.74


What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test is the gold-standard evaluation for central precocious puberty. However, this is not a useful test in a patient whose LH and FSH levels are elevated in the setting of primary gonadal failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by low testosterone levels, with inappropriately normal or low levels of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). This condition can result from hypothalamic or pituitary defects in gonadotropin secretion. Hyperprolactinemia, hypothalamic or pituitary tumor, ischemia, and infiltrative disease are known causes of acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Brain MRI would be helpful in the evaluation of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism to assess for a hypothalamic or pituitary defect, but this evaluation is not indicated in this patient, who has primary gonadal failure.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has delayed progression of puberty (adrenarche at age 11 but minimal testicular enlargement) and gynecomastia. His testosterone level is in the early pubertal range, but his follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are substantially elevated, consistent with primary gonadal failure (also known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism). The differential diagnosis of primary gonadal failure in boys includes congenital causes, such as Klinefelter syndrome and congenital cryptorchidism, and acquired causes, such as trauma, infection, radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune conditions, and infiltrative diseases.

Klinefelter syndrome is the most common congenital cause of primary hypogonadism in males, with an incidence of 150 per 100,000. The most likely karyotype is 47,XXY, although mosaicism is common. Manifestations include small testicular volume (<6 mL) with azoospermia and infertility, low-normal to low testosterone levels in many adolescents, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, gynecomastia, learning disabilities with speech delay, metabolic syndrome, and psychiatric disorders. The most appropriate next step for this patient is to obtain a karyotype to assess for Klinefelter syndrome and confirm the suspected diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most common congenital cause of primary hypogonadism in males is Klinefelter syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has primary gonadal failure, his testicles are palpable (thus, no concern for cryptorchidism), and there is no testicular mass reported; therefore, a testicular ultrasound is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by low testosterone levels, with inappropriately normal or low levels of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). This condition can result from hypothalamic or pituitary defects in gonadotropin secretion. Hyperprolactinemia, hypothalamic or pituitary tumor, ischemia, and infiltrative disease are known causes of acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Serum prolactin levels would be helpful in the evaluation of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism to assess for hyperprolactinemia, but this evaluation is not indicated in this patient, who has primary gonadal failure.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of erectile dysfunction. He reports difficulty maintaining an erection during intercourse and rarely has morning erections. He is satisfied with his current relationship but notes decreased sexual desire and feels embarrassed about his sexual performance. He sustained a lumbar vertebral injury one year ago in a motor vehicle accident. He takes medication for schizophrenia but cannot recall the name. On examination, he has testicular atrophy; the remainder of the genital examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Afferent fibers from the pudendal nerve transmit sensory stimuli from the external genitalia and perineum to the parasympathetic nervous system, where efferent signals are generated to mediate an erection. Damage to peripheral nerves can interfere with this neural pathway and lead to neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction. This patient has no symptoms of neurologic disorders and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by peripheral nerve injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Peyronie disease is a fibroproliferative disorder affecting the tunica albuginea of the penis. Patients typically present with penile pain, curving of the penis during an erection, and/or palpable nodules and induration of the penis. This patient has no signs or symptoms of Peyronie disease and his testicular atrophy suggests a different cause of his sexual dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics can cause erectile dysfunction and hypogonadism due to their effects as dopamine antagonists and subsequent disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Dopamine antagonists stimulate prolactin secretion, which leads to the downstream effects of decreased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus, decreased LH secretion from the anterior pituitary, and decreased production of testosterone by Leydig cells in the testes. This results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which would explain this patient's erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and testicular atrophy.

Key learning point: Antipsychotic-induced hyperprolactinemia can suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to decreased testosterone, hypogonadism, erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and testicular atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychologic stressors (e.g., depression, previous traumatic experiences, relationship trouble) are common causes of erectile dysfunction. Patients with psychogenic erectile dysfunction usually get morning erections, but have difficulty getting or maintaining erections during intercourse with a partner. This patient rarely has morning erections and presents with testicular atrophy, making psychologic stressors an unlikely primary cause for his sexual dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Microvascular disease is a very common cause of erectile dysfunction in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and/or smoking history. Microvascular disease causes endothelial dysfunction and decreased levels of nitric oxide, thereby impairing vasodilation of vessels supplying the corpus cavernosum. However, this patient lacks cardiovascular risk factors and presents with testicular atrophy, which would not be explained by microvascular disease.
questions.hint: This patient with schizophrenia is likely being treated with an atypical antipsychotic. These medications can cause hyperprolactinemia, leading to sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because she has not yet attained menarche. She has no history of serious illness. Her height and weight are at the 50th percentile. On examination, there is no glandular breast tissue and no pubic hair development. Pelvic examination is normal. The remainder of the examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is only indicated if FSH levels are low and a hypothalamic or pituitary disease (e.g., pituitary tumor) is suspected, which could cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and subsequent primary amenorrhea. This patient does not present with additional symptoms of a process in the sella region, such as headaches, vision changes, or any other signs of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

The GnRH stimulation test is the gold standard for identifying central precocious puberty. This patient lacks signs of puberty such as menarche and breast development and requires further evaluation of primary amenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

The progesterone challenge test is indicated in suspected gonadotropin deficiency (low FSH, LH, and estrogen). Gonadotropin levels of this patient have not been measured yet, therefore, another step is more appropriate at this point.

D) CORRECT:

The evaluation of primary amenorrhea starts with a pelvic examination and a pregnancy test to rule out pregnancy. If pelvic examination confirms the presence of a uterus, serum FSH level should be assessed. A high serum FSH level indicates gonadal dysgenesis, most commonly due to chromosomal aberrations, e.g., in Turner syndrome (45,XO). Causes of a low serum FSH level include constitutional growth delay, functional growth delay (e.g., due to inflammatory bowel disease or chronic kidney disease), and hypothalamic-pituitary disorders (e.g., hemochromatosis, injury, Kallmann syndrome). Further testing depends on the suspected etiology and includes serum TSH and prolactin levels to rule out uncommon causes of primary amenorrhea (e.g., hyperprolactinemia due to prolactinoma, hypothyroidism).

In patients with blind or absent vagina on pelvic examination, a pelvic ultrasound should be performed to visualize internal reproductive organs. Congenital reproductive outflow tract obstruction (e.g., imperforate hymen) should be considered if a uterus is present. In patients without a uterus on ultrasound, serum testosterone levels and karyotyping are used to determine the underlying pathology (e.g., Mullerian agenesis, androgen insensitivity syndrome).

Key learning point: In primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics and a normal uterus, the initial evaluation should include measurement of serum FSH to distinguish between gonadal and central causes.

Depending on the result of the serum FSH studies, the working diagnosis for this patient could be either gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Swyer syndrome) or a hypothalamic-pituitary disorder (e.g., normosmic isolated GnRH deficiency). Functional or constitutional growth delays are unlikely as the patient is in the 50th percentile for weight and height.

E) INCORRECT:

All patients who have not reached menarche by the age of 16 years or have not developed secondary sexual characteristics (breasts, pubic hair) by the age of 13 years must be evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Further tests should be initiated to identify correctable causes and initiate treatment, if necessary.
questions.hint: Absent or incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 14 years in boys or 13 years in girls indicates delayed puberty. This delay can be constitutional, secondary to underlying conditions, or due to hypogonadism.
